header_summary:
Jonas Nick, Liam Eagen, Robin Linus, and their team have introduced a significant advancement in cryptocurrency protocols with the Shielded CSV whitepaper, which presents a novel method for improving transaction privacy and efficiency through "Proof-Carrying Data" and reducing the blockchain data footprint to just 64 bytes per transaction. This approach not only enhances privacy by concealing the transaction graph but also proposes a scalability solution capable of supporting up to 100 transactions per second on Bitcoin, marking a departure from traditional CSV implementations ([Shielded CSV whitepaper](https://github.com/ShieldedCSV/ShieldedCSV/releases/latest/download/shieldedcsv.pdf)).

Renepickhardt highlights the potential benefits and challenges of incorporating multiparty channel constructs in payment channel networks, emphasizing improvements in payment reliability and service level guarantees. However, he also points out the need for further research into the drawbacks, particularly regarding on-chain bandwidth and unilateral exit costs, along with compatibility issues with current pathfinding algorithms, suggesting that multiparty channels might inadvertently affect network routing capabilities ([Multiparty Channel Constructs](https://github.com/renepickhardt/Lightning-Network-Limitations/blob/305db330c96dc751f0615d9abb096b12b8a6191f/Limits%20of%20two%20party%20channels/paper/a%20mathematical%20theory%20of%20payment%20channel%20networks.pdf)).

Andy Schroder introduces `Lightning Cheques`, a novel paper-based payment method for the Lightning Network, designed to facilitate offline transactions. This method, which involves pre-generated QR codes for transactions, mirrors the tangible exchange of cash and addresses scenarios like gifting, travel, and providing financial solutions for those with limited technology access, yet introduces a trust element similar to traditional cash transactions regarding the issuance of change ([Lightning Cheques](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/privately-sending-payments-while-offline-with-bolt12/1134)).

Virtu presents a novel DNS encoding method that incorporates Tor, I2P, and CJDNS addresses into AAAA records, demonstrating an innovative approach to integrating alternative network addresses within the DNS system. Despite the encoding efficiency being around 50% due to overhead, this method offers seamless operation with existing DNS resolution tools and does not negatively affect server-side caching mechanisms, suggesting a trade-off between encoding efficiency and address type versatility ([DNS Encoding Method](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/hardcoded-seeds-dns-seeds-and-darknet-nodes/1123/11)).

recent_posts.title: Shielded CSV: Private and Efficient Client-Side Validation
recent_posts.summary:
- Liam Eagen and Robin Linus developed the Shielded CSV whitepaper to improve cryptocurrency privacy.
- Shielded CSV minimizes data on the blockchain, offering more privacy and scalability in transactions.
- The protocol signifies advances in efficiency and privacy, capable of supporting up to 100 transactions per second.

recent_posts.title: A Lightning Network of multi-party mechanisms
recent_posts.summary:
- Expanding protocols to include multiparty channels enhances payment reliability.
- Concerns exist about on-chain costs and compatibility with pathfinding algorithms.
- Careful consideration is needed to address challenges without affecting routing efficiency.

recent_posts.title: Lightning Cheques
recent_posts.summary:
- Lightning Cheques offer a paper-based, offline cryptocurrency transaction method via Lightning Network.
- They enable merchants to process payments and issue change through QR-encoded invoice requests and offers.
- Proposals aim to improve security and versatility, including gifting and travel, enhancing physical transaction options.

recent_posts.title: Hardcoded seeds, DNS seeds and Darknet nodes
recent_posts.summary:
- A novel method encodes network addresses in DNS AAAA records, with about 50% efficiency.
- It uses ff00::/8 IPv6 prefix, allowing encoding of onion, I2P, and CJDNS addresses without affecting DNS tools.
- Eleven AAAA records can represent two addresses from each network, ensuring standard IPv6 operations remain unaffected.

active_posts.title: Adding New BIP Editors
active_posts.summary:
- Luke's inability to manage the BIPs repository necessitates additional BIP editors.
- Proposed editors, Kanzure and RubenSomsen, are expected to enhance the BIP process.
- New editors must align on BIP numbering and have a solid Bitcoin development background.

active_posts.title: Public disclosure of 1 vulnerability affecting Bitcoin Core <24.0.1
active_posts.summary:
- The Bitcoin Core team disclosed a new vulnerability update.
- A new policy for disclosing security vulnerabilities has been implemented.
- Future updates will address vulnerabilities in versions prior to 25.0 next month.

active_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 28.0 Release Candidate 2 Available
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v28.0rc2 binaries are now available for download.
- The update is critical for rigorous testing before the official version 28.0 launch.
- Release candidate serves to identify issues through real-world testing before widespread deployment.

active_posts.title: PPLNS with job declaration
active_posts.summary:
- Development of an SV2 extension for fairer mining payouts is underway.
- The extension grants miners the ability to choose transactions and fee structures.
- The project seeks reviews to refine its system, based on PPLNS enhancements.

active_posts.title: Who will run the CoinJoin coordinators?
active_posts.summary:
- The crackdown on privacy tools has altered the Bitcoin privacy service landscape.
- New alternatives and tools, like BTCPay Server CoinJoin plugin, are gaining traction.
- The future of Bitcoin privacy techniques and decentralized coordinator networks remains uncertain.

active_posts.title: Proving UTXO set inclusion in zero-knowledge
active_posts.summary:
- The `utxozkp` tool enhances LN privacy by proving UTXO set inclusion in zero knowledge.
- It significantly improves anti-DOS capabilities and aims for future enhancements in detail revelation.
- Performance metrics include a 6-minute proof generation and a 1.4 MB proof size on M1 Max.

today_in_history_posts.title: BIP draft: OP_CHECKBLOCKATHEIGHT
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Luke Dashjr has proposed OP_CHECKBLOCKATHEIGHT for Bitcoin to address double-spending.
- He shared the proposal on GitHub and is seeking feedback on its merit.
- Rusty suggests a three-arg version for gambling games but fears it may harm CBAH.

today_in_history_posts.title: Single channel on mobile clients
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Multiple phone channels for third-party payments pose risks and user decision-making challenges.
- Users often prefer simplicity over managing payment channel details like fees and fund limits.
- Solutions include educating users on balance dimensions or recombining channels, though issues remain.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin scaling involves creating 50,000 off-chain entities for weekly billion-user transactions.
- The approach includes federated sidechains and coinpools without trusting a third party.
- Solutions focus on layer 2 protocols, with safety and regulatory compliance as priorities.
